title: indonesia volcano erupts tsunami earthquake mount soputan sulawesi
story: Created with Sketch.Join us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the options'People talk about the butterfly effect. The concept is that when a butterfly flaps its wings, it can cause a catastrophe'Click to followThe IndependentA volcano on the Indonesian island of Sulawesi has started to spew lava causing an ash plume to rise two-and-a-half miles into the air.&nbspMount&nbspSoputan&nbsperupted days after a powerful earthquake and devastating tsunami rocked the island, killing more than 1,400 people and injuring hundreds more.&nbspOfficials believe the death toll will rise over the coming days and weeks.&nbspAlthough the volcano is situated hundreds of miles from the where the tsunami hit,&nbspthere are fears that the ash that has been spewed into the sky could hamper aid efforts.Appeal launched for Indonesia earthquake as aid begins to arriveVolcano erupts on same island as earthquake-stricken city of PaluWhat is liquefaction and what role did it play in Indonesia?Over 1,200 confirmed dead after Indonesian earthquake and tsunamiA government volcanologist said it was possible the eruption was accelerated by the magnitude 7.5 earthquake that struck late last week.&nbspIt could be that this earthquake triggered the eruption, but we have seen an increase in volcanic activity since July and this began surging on Monday. Yet we can't say there a direct link, as the mountain is quite far away, said&nbspthe head of Indonesia's Volcanology and Geology Disaster Mitigation Agency, said on local television.&nbspKasbani, who only uses one name, said planes were warned to avoid the area as volcanic ash is hazardous to plane engines.National disaster agency spokesman Sutopo Purwo Nugroho&nbsptold a separate&nbspnews conference in Indonesia's capital&nbspJakarta, that no residential areas are within the 4-kilometre danger radius.&nbspThe volcano agency said the public should avoid the area nearest the volcano and masks would be made available in the event of ash fall.&nbspNazli Ismail, a geophysicist at the University of Syiah Kuala in Banda Aceh on Sumatra island, stressed there was no concrete evidence to show the two incidents are linked.&nbspPeople talk about the butterfly effect. The concept is that when a butterfly flaps its wings, it can cause a catastrophe, he said.&nbspSo it is possible for the earthquake to trigger the volcano eruption, but it's not conclusive. story: Theresa May has recently come away from the Conservative Party Conference with renewed vigour, dancing onto the stage to Abba's 'Dancing Queen'.&nbspShe hasn't wasted any time either, as she has bounced back from disappointing Brexit negotaitions two weeks ago with a whole new plan for a customs union.&nbspTitled an 'all-UK customs union', the newest plan seeks to break a new deal with the EU.&nbspHer newest plan has already received praise, and could mark a step up in terms of succesful negotiations.&nbsp                Brexit COUNTDOWN: The UK&rsquos three options left if Chequers IS chuckedWhat is an 'all-UK customs union'?The all-UK customs union seeks to avoud a hard border with Ireland by having the UK and EU participate in a customs union together.&nbspA customs union between the UK and EU countries would mean free trade and common import duties would exist between themThis would solve the Irish border issue as the Prime Minister would be agreeing to have Northern Ireland remain a part of the single market regulatory area of the EU.&nbspHer plan has won support from Irish officials, but some are wondering if it truly constitutes a fully-fledged Brexit.&nbspTheresa May Brexit news- Prime Minister receives support for all-UK customs union (Image: )

story: Mrs May is said to be pouring over the plan, which &ldquois for the whole UK to participate in a customs union with the EU, and is a scenario that could take effect if no other solution to the Irish border question is found.The plan would act as a temporary deal with the EU until a final solution to the Northern Ireland border enigma that has so far stifled Brexit negotiations is finally solved.An unnamed source told the Financial Times that officials in Dublin &ldquoprivately argue it could settle the border question and open the way to a deal.EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier has already rejected the idea, according to the FT source.                Theresa May really gave the speech of a lifetime, says LEO McKINSTRY                Brilliant Mrs May showed Britain she is in charge &ndash EXPRESS COMMENTIrish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar and Barnier are meeting later today to discuss the border issue in depth.The Irish border has been a massive stumbling block since Brexit negotiations began in the wake of the June 2016 EU referendum that saw 52 percent of Britain vote to leave the EU.But a solution to the issue needs to be found before the UK leaves the bloc on 29 March 2019.There had been suggestions that Northern Ireland could remain part of the EU&rsquos customs union, yet the new plan Mrs May is said to be working on could see the rest of the UK also remain tied to EU trade rules and regulations.Mrs May is said to be pouring over the plan (Image: )Leo Varadkar and Barnier are meeting later today to discuss the border (Image: )This would scrap the need for tariffs on goods transported between the Irish Republic and the UK, and could even prevent the need for a hard border all together, as well as costly and complicated customs checks.The temporary extension of the customs union would also prevent Northern Ireland being cast out of the UK.It comes after Mrs May delivered a keynote speech at the Conservative Party conference, where she insisted Britain&rsquos post-Brexit future is &ldquofull of promise.Mrs May said: Those of us who do respect the result need to come together now if we don&rsquot - if we all go off in different directions in pursuit of our vision of the perfect Brexit we risk having no Brexit at all.

title: Daily horoscope is it real astrology zodiac star reading
story: Daily horoscopes: Scientists are not convinced astrology is a legitimate field  (Image: )Astrology is the esoteric study of the stars and planets on the premise the heavenly bodies rule or influence events on Earth.The planets and stars all align with the 12 astrological signs, known as the zodiac, which themselves derive from Babylonian mythology.Today, daily horoscopes are read to answer questions about the future, personal relationships and financial concerns.From an outsider's viewpoint, astrology might seem scientific because it tracks the positions of stars and the planets &ndash but is it in any way real?                Monthly horoscope for October: What is YOUR zodiac reading forecast?                Daily Horoscope on October 4: Star sign reading, zodiac, astrology In Understanding Science - How Science Really Works - a series for the UC Museum of Palaeontology, UC Berkeley said there are zero cases of astrology contributing to any scientific discovery.University of Berkeley, CaliforniaSimilarly, astrologers do not use the scientific method to create their predictions and forecasts are typically too vague to be trusted.UC Berkeley wrote: &ldquoIn the few cases where astrology has been used to generate testable expectations and the results were examined in a careful study, the evidence did not support the validity of astrological ideas.&ldquoThis experience is common in science &mdash scientists often test ideas that turn out to be wrong.                October Horoscope: Monthly horoscope prediction, zodiac and astrology&ldquoHowever, one of the hallmarks of science is that ideas are modified when warranted by the evidence.&ldquoAstrology has not changed its ideas in response to contradictory evidence.Another major problem is most people are under the impression they were born under one particular zodiac sign when in reality they are completely different.This happens because the zodiac, as it was created thousands of years ago, did not account for the Earth wobbling in its orbit around the Sun.Daily horoscopes track the Sun and the Moon's position in the zodiacs (Image: )Daily horoscope: There are 12 signs in the commonly used zodiac calendar (Image: )This wobble, known as precession, has caused the intersecting point between the celestial equator and the Sun&rsquos ecliptic in the sky to shift by 36 degrees.Over the 2,500 years that people have been using the zodiac to predetermine their lives, the signs have moved into different positions and are invalid today.For instance, a person born between March 21 and April 19 might think they are an&nbspAries,&nbspwhen in reality they were born in Pisces.The Sun&rsquos recession moved each sign by almost an entire month, further questioning the validity of daily horoscopes.

title: Daily Horoscope zodiac wrong star signs NASA
story: Daily horoscopes are wrong according to NASA's astronomers (Image: )When the Sun passes through the skies along the so-called ecliptic, astrologers track which zodiac the Sun moves through.This is believed to have esoteric power and influence over our lives and daily routines.Similarly, the Moon and the planets all move through the zodiac on a daily basis, giving rise to daily horoscopes, zodiacs and forecasts.But a particular way in which the Earth wobbles around the Sun paired with a missing constellation could throw all of this out the window &ndash NASA explained why.                Monthly horoscope for October: What is YOUR zodiac reading forecast?                Daily Horoscope on October 4: Star sign reading, zodiac, astrology When the ancient Babylonians devised the zodiac nearly 3,000 years ago, the astrological signs were based on the Sun&rsquos movements at the time.The Babylonian established 12 constellations in the zodiac calendar despite the fact there were actually 13 zodiacs.NASA said: &ldquoTo make a tidy match with their 12-month calendar, the Babylonians ignored the fact that the Sun actually moves through 13 constellations, not 12.&ldquoThen they assigned each of those 12 constellations equal amounts of time.&ldquoBesides the 12 familiar constellations of the zodiac, the Sun is also aligned with Ophiuchus for about 18 days each year.Ophiuchus is the missing 13th constellation avoided by the Babylonians so that the zodiac would fit their pre-existing 12-month calendar.The zodiac constellations are also different shapes and sizes, meaning the Sun spends varying amounts of time in each.For instance, the line extending from the Earth through the Sun towards Virgo lasts around 45 days.                October Horoscope: Monthly horoscope prediction, zodiac and astrology                Daily Horoscope: Fact or fiction - Are horoscopes and astrology real?But if you were to track the Sun&rsquos position in Scorpio, it would only last seven days.There is also the issue of precession and the Sun no longer moving through the sky in the same way it did 3,000 years ago.As the Earth barrels around the Sun, the planet wobbles on its orbit as a result of the gravitational attraction between the Moon and the equatorial bulge.Day-to-day the wobble is inconsequential but over thousands of years since the Babylonians, the Sun&rsquos ecliptic has shifted by about 36 degrees.Daily horoscopes: The modern zodiac calendar was devised by the ancient Babylonians (Image: )Daily Horoscope: Astronomers claim the zodiac is out of synch with the Sun (Image: )As a result, the zodiac constellations have moved their positions to be approximately one month out of synch with your daily horoscopes.Someone born under the sign of Aries most likely was born under the sign of Pisces and so on.Below are the updated horoscope dates, which take into account the Sun&rsquos precession.Capricorn &ndash January 20 to February 16.Aquarius &ndash February 16 to March 11.Pisces &ndash March 11 to April 18.Aries &ndash April 18 to May 13.Taurus &ndash May 13 to June 21.Gemini &ndash June 21 to July 20.Cancer &ndash July 20 to August 10.Leo &ndash August 10 to September 16.Virgo &ndash September 16 to October 30.Libra &ndash October 30 to November 23.Scorpio &ndash November 23 to November 29.Ophiuchus &ndash November 29 to December 17.Sagittarius &ndash December 17 to January 20.

title: Brexit news update Tim Martin Wetherspoons Femi UK EU trade deal
story: The Wetherspoons boss was questioned by Mr Oluwole on the UK's post-Brexit trade opportunities and to give an example of any nation in the world trading with countries that are not on the same continent.&nbspWhen Mr Martin gave the valid example of Australia, the young Remainer argued that the top countries Australia trades food with are the ones that are geographically closed to it.&nbspBut the prominent Brexiteer hit back replying: &ldquoI think the point is we can still trade with the EU under World Trade Organisation rules.And when Mr Olwole claimed trading&nbspunder WTO rules would increase&nbsptariffs and make food more expensive, Mr Martin said: No, the opposite.                Pound to euro exchange rate: Sterling advances despite no-deal threat                Farage warns THIS aspect of May's speech signals Brexit to get worseHe added: &ldquoWe can have zero tariffs on imports from the entire world once we leave the EU.It comes as the Prime Minister&nbsptold Tory delegates at the Conservative Party Conference in Birmingham that striking a frictionless trade deal with Brussels would secure the certainty British business will need to operate in the future.In her speech, Mrs May said:&nbspOur proposal is for a free trade deal that provides for frictionless trade in goods.It would protect hundreds of thousands of jobs in the just-in-time supply chains our manufacturing firms rely on.Businesses wouldn&rsquot face costly checks when they export to the EU, so they can invest with confidence.Brexit news: Tim Martin shuts down Femi Oluwole on post-Brexit trade (Image: FEMI OLUWOLE&bullTWITTER)And it would protect our precious Union &ndash the seamless border in Northern Ireland, a bedrock of peace and stability, would see no change whatsoever.No simple free trade agreement could achieve that, not even one that makes use of the very latest technology.She added: Our proposal would mean we could renew our role in the world, strike new trade deals with other countries.With control of our money, we can spend more on our NHS.With control of our laws, we can bring decision-making closer to the people and returning powers to Westminster, Edinburgh, Cardiff and Belfast.And with control of our borders, we can do something that no British government has been able to do in decades &ndash restore full and complete control of who comes into this country to the democratically elected representatives of the British people.A strong critic of the Prime Minister's Brexit strategy, Nigel Farage has claimed Mrs May's focus on frictionless trade in her conference speech was a sign a much worse deal than her Chequers plan would be reached at the end of the negotiations with Brussels.&nbspHe warned: There was a phrase in her speech that I think commentators really properly noticed. Frictionless trade, what does that mean? That means, basically, the deal has been done.This isn&rsquot just going to be Chequers, which she couldn&rsquot even mention because she knew she might get a little bit of abuse from the floor.This, by the time she comes back in the afternoon of 19 October, will be much worse than any of the Eurosceptics feared Chequers was going to be.

title: Man shed 40 years Carlisle Cumbria modern slavery latest news
story: An investigation is underway after a British man was found in a padlocked six-foot shed (Image: Getty)The Gangmasters and Labour Abuse Authority (GLAA), who acted on a tip-toff and rescued the man yesterday morning, suspects the 58-year-old had been held in the tiny and decrepit shack in Carlisle, Cumbria, since the age of 18.The potential modern slavery victim has now been taken to be medically examined by specialist trauma officers.Martin Plimmer from the GLAA said: The information that was given to us was that he had been kept in the shed for a period of 40 years.When we found him he was like a rabbit in headlights and very confused.                'Showbiz Sadiq' attacked for favouring 'red carpet over community'                Mexico: Holiday resort plagued by shocking violent crimesHe was just in the clothes he stood up in and where he was sleeping in the shed there was just a soiled duvet on the floor.There was no heating and it was very cold.&ldquoIt was conditions that no human being should live in.Mr Plimmer added that he suspects the victim was forced to carry out unpaid work from the age of 16 or 17.The victim appears to have been living there only with filthy bed sheets and a garden chair (Image: PA)A 79-year-old British man has been arrested on suspicion of modern slavery offences.Mr Plimmer added: In my long career I've never come across anyone who has been held as a slave potentially for 40 years and this, I think, could be the longest period of captivity that we have dealt with.It's an extremely sad and serious case.Pictures from the scene show the inside of the shed, and the victim appears to have been living there only with filthy bed sheets, a garden chair and a broken electric heater.UK prison staff hospitalised following BRUTAL brawl during riot 'GET A GRIP&rsquo Tory MP attacks Sadiq Khan&rsquos approach to violent crimeThe potential modern slavery victim has now been taken to be medically examined by specialists (Image: PA)A statement released by the GLAA reads: &ldquoThe operation has been supported by specialist officers from the National Crime Agency, the Cumbria Housing Department who are investigating possible health and safety breaches, and officers from Cumbria Police.Modern slavery exists in a whole range of forms across the UK.If you suspect someone is being exploited or abused, please do not hesitate to get in contact with us.Your call could be the difference between exploitation continuing and worsening or a victim being rescued and given the support that they desperately need.

title: Brexit news Nicola Sturgeon Scotland Independence Referendum latest
story: The Scottish First Minister claimed she would support a Brexit People's Vote in the event Theresa May called for one but argued a second referendum on EU membership would not guarantee salvation for Scotland.&nbspUrged to back the second EU referendum campaign by Scottish Liberal Democrat MSP Willie Rennie, Ms Sturgeon claimed the so-called People's Vote will not guarantee Brexit will not be imposed on Remain-backing Scotland.She said: &ldquoWe don&rsquot stand in the way of a People&rsquos Vote if there&rsquos a People&rsquos Vote I&rsquod be perfectly happy with that.&ldquoBut it doesn&rsquot guarantee salvation for Scotland and we saw in 2016.                Brexit news: Why Ruth Davidson will NEVER call for second Brexit vote                 May says Sturgeon is BETRAYING SCOTLAND with fishing industry plans&ldquoSo when Willie Rennie is right about one thing: it is really serious.&ldquoThe Tories are leading Scotland to disaster and the last few days we&rsquove had warnings of recession, medicine shortages, pressure on food supply.&ldquoWe&rsquove seen the cancellation of a clinical trial at the Golden Jubilee Hospital.&ldquoBut that for me makes this point clearer than ever.&ldquoScotland needs the option of independence because only independence guarantees that these things can&rsquot be imposed on us against our will.Brexit news: Nicola Sturgeon laughed at as she claims second Indy Referendum is the only salvation (Image: SCOTTISH PARLIAMENT)Last month,&nbspthe Scottish First Minister received the stark warning from cross-party Unionist campaign group Scottish Business UK, on the fourth anniversary of the Scottish independence referendum in 2014, which resulted in the country not winning independence from the rest of the UK.The campaign group warned the SNP leader that damaging Scotland&rsquos trade with the rest of the UK would be far greater than the potential losses that the UK could face as a result of exiting the European Union (EU) in March next year.Scottish Business UK said employers would struggle under the pressure of added uncertainty as tensions grow over the fate of the UK post-Brexit in a new report published on Tuesday.The report, titled Win-Win: the business case for Scotland&rsquos place in the UK, said Scotland&rsquos independence would be more disastrous than a doomsday Brexit scenario as the country would lose additional government spending per head under the Barnett Formula.The report also highlighted figures that showed trade between Scotland and other parts of the UK was three times more valuable as Scotland&rsquos trade with the EU.Scottish Business UK founder Robert Kilgour said: Scottish businesses and the economy has gone through an extended period of uncertainty and that is de-stabilising our opportunity to grow and crucially to secure inward investment.&ldquoThe negative impact of the continuing uncertainty is a message I hear regularly from investors who turn to other countries or regions in England, to give their investments a more stable base from which to grow.The campaign group&rsquos chief executive, former MEP Struan Stevenson, backed up the independent report and called for the government to &ldquoabandon the pursuit of another referendum.

title: Brexit news Jean Claude Juncker EU UK Ireland border deal latest
story: Brexit news: Jean-Claude Juncker believes UK always creates dramas in EU negotiations (Image: )The European Commission President has a long history of thorny negotiations with the British ever since becoming the EU&rsquos most senior official in 2014.So much so, he has previously joked to colleagues that talks with a deal with the British can often end with &ldquothree dramas, three protocols and 15 side declarations.Mr Juncker made the comments even before Britons voted to leave the EU, which displays there has always been a level of friction between the bloc and Westminster.On negotiating with the British, he revealed to one colleague: &ldquoThere are always three dramas, and you end up at the end with three protocols and 15 side declarations.&ldquoIt is always like that.But this doesn&rsquot mean a soft spot for Britain doesn&rsquot exist inside Mr Juncker&rsquos heart.During a recent citizens&rsquo dialogue in Germany, former Luxembourg prime minister quipped: &ldquoI recently reminded the U.K. prime minister that there are only two great member states in the EU: Great Britain and the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg.&ldquoSo there will soon be only one of them.                Brexit news: Tusk warns UK to start showing EU respect amid Hunt row                Barnier believes May could DROP Chequers to reach Brexit deal with EUHe added: &ldquoWe are right in the middle of these difficult Brexit negotiations and I am totally for finding a good way to cooperate with the Brits as friends.The Commission President's experience of fractious UK-EU negotiations may have dampened his mood while the rest of Brussels seems to have perked up in hope of impending deal.Both sides have been trapped by an impasse on the Irish border solution as they fail to reach a consensus on the so-called backstop mechanism.Even without announcing anything of substance, Leo Varadkar pushed for a November deal after meeting with European Council President Donald Tusk.The Irish prime minister told reporters: I want to see an agreement by November if at all possible.European leaders will next convene in Brussels for the October European Council summit in little over two weeks time.The Belgian capital will play host to an EU27 Brexit dinner debate on October 17, specially organised as negotiators look to rush through a number of agreements in the next week.The European Commission has earmarked October 10 for the release of a political declaration designed to outline the future trading partnership between Britain and EU.Britain&rsquos official date of quitting the EU remains March 29, 2019 but this document will reveal crucial information allowing Britons an early opportunity to discover what life after the Brussels project will be like.The political declaration will act as a grand tease as the Prime Minister and Brussels use the &lsquocarrot-and-stick&rsquo approach to ensure the withdrawal agreement passes smoothly through their retrospective parliaments.However, there is a huge sticking point both sides will be looking to remain coy about &ndash the highly anticipated document will not be legally binding, which will allow EU bosses to make a number of last-minute changes and eleventh-hour reversals in the hope of keeping Britain politically locked to their project.

story: The Brexiteer MP warned of the huge uncertainty a second Brexit referendum would cause for business and the British economy.Speaking on Channel 4 News, Mr Raab said: &ldquoThere is no doubt that there has been some uncertainty as a result of the Brexit process &ndash no doubt about it. story: Theresa May vowed the resilience and ingenuity of the British people will see us through Brexit during her conference speech. story: Phil Campion, a former SAS Trooper and author called for the return of the Royal Tournament, which was held by the British Armed Forces annually between 1880 to 1999.Theresa May has scheduled 2022 as the year to hold a &pound120million &lsquoFestival of Britain&rsquo, but Mr Campion said the UK should bring back the Royal Tournament.Speaking on Sky News&rsquo The Pledge, the former SAS veteran claimed the Royal Tournament was &ldquoa celebration of the men and women who really make this country great before he took a swipe at the EU.He said: &ldquoSo Theresa May, in a bid to embrace our freedom from the EU, has hatched a plan for a festival of all things British. title: theresa may brave brexit vote
story: In the largest vote ever recorded in Britain, we chose to leave the Brussels racket.And as she reveals in our exclusive interview, Theresa May is determined to tell the world that we are getting out, no s, no buts.Tory Conference this week will be testy. Let’s hear their ideas and a real vision of what Britain can be.IT is disgraceful that major food stores are exploiting a legal loophole to avoid showing ingredients on packaging.Teenager Natasha Ednan-Laperouse’s death should serve as a warning of how dangerous this practice is.The law states that when food is prepared onsite, ingredients labelling is not necessary. It is designed to protect small, independent stores.But our investigation today reveals large chains have not learnt from this avoidable tragedy.Pret a Manger was warned nine times about the dangers of sesame seed in its artisan baguettes and yet it continues to sell items without allergy warnings.Now Natasha’s mother Tanya has challenged the chain to lobby for a change in our labelling laws.And, hopefully, stop other parents having to suffer such a terrible loss.BON appétit, M’luds. title: philip hammond brexit speech trevor kavanagh opinion
story: He is also writing his ­Halloween Budget on October . Nobody is hoping for voter-friendly treats.For a man in charge of our economic destiny at such a momentous time, this “stubby-pencilled accountant” has precious little to say. It seems he even remained mute at a recent Cabinet session to war-game a No-Deal Brexit — surely the Chancellor of the Exchequer’s special subject.Well-informed Spectator editor Fraser Nelson says other ministers piled in with upbeat projects but Hammond “seemed to have no ideas and kept quiet”. Spreadsheet Phil possesses either supreme self-confidence or total contempt for the .million who voted for Brexit, or both.The man who a year ago faced political death has become the most powerful figure in Theresa May’s Cabinet — perhaps including herself.She remains the figurehead. But the minister she planned to axe until her botched General Election is running the Brexit show from his Treasury eyrie.Hammond’s sympathetic image as Eeyore, a woebegone soft toy, is misleading. This man combines thin-skinned arrogance with a rare combination of political disabilities — cloth-eared, ham-fisted and leaden-footed.The grey image of bungled Budgets and barren creativity stands in vivid contrast to his outrageous Project Fear scaremongering. Mrs May certainly deserves blame for her hapless EU negotiations and the mutant Chequers plan for a Hi-HoBrexit.THE Tories have made a decent start to their conference – but they need to set their ambitions higher.Last week the Labour Party promised easy answers on everything from housing to the economy. It was a radical,utterly disastrous, vision for Britain.The Government changing tipping rules and increasing taxes on foreign property buyers is pretty small beer.Not least since the former was first announced three years ago and the latter is pretty much copied from last year’s Labour manesto.Philip Hammond — rarely mistaken for a ray of sunshine — needs to provide light at the end of the austerity tunnel.He must lay the groundwork for entrepreneurs to thrive in a newly liberated, unapologetically free market economy.And he should challenge business to work with him, too. The self-appointed “voices of British business”, iniably dominated by large corporate interests, push every day for more and more Brexit concessions.Yet as last week showed, Labour’s unreconstructed Marxism is a far more serious threat to future prosperity than any kind of Brexit.It’s time for big businesses to play their part in building a better Britain, rather than refighting a referendum which was as much a vote against them as the political establishment.Eeyore Hammond must encourage them to invest in Britain’s future.She survived last year’s election catastrophe only because Remainers feared a true Brexiteer such as Boris Johnson might replace her.Hammond has since deployed his Treasury reach to capitalise on her weakness and box us into BRINO — Brexit In Name Only. Mrs May is the willing captive of passionate Remainers in Downing Street, Whitehall, the Cabinet Office and, crucially, the all-powerful Treasury.Since the departure of close aide Nick Timothy, there is nobody within earshot who voted Brexit — including Mrs May. Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab, like his predecessor David Davis, has virtually no say in negotiations.Hammond now calls the shots, backed by panic-stirring Business Secretary Greg Clark and Europhile Cabinet Office minister David Lidington.Brexiteers fear this Unholy Trinity is ready for more concessions over issues including migration, EU benefits and Britain’s vital financial services industry.Never forget, it was Hammond who blocked all spending and therefore all serious preparation for No Deal, a prospect now apparently facing this nation. In fact there was never a chance of No Deal.We will end up with a form of Chequers, but one even more pro-Brussels than the proposal which saw David Davis and BoJo storm out. Remainers are back in full Project Fear mode.European car firms are happily pouring billions into Britain — despite Brexit. Yet Greg Clark triggered last week’s chorus of fake alarm from Toyota, claiming its “just-in-time” supply chain would grind to a halt.This ignores the whole point of “just-in-time”. It is designed specically to cope with delivery glitches and operates worldwide in all circumstances under global trade rules.It was also Clark who handed Brussels its biggest anti-Brexit card by promising those shroud-waving car giants the UK would remain under EU rules. That led directly to Mrs May’s surrender over the Northern Ireland border, which has plagued negotiations ever since.It is a tragic fact — but no surprise — that we are now heading remorselessly for a deal on EU terms at our expense.EU leaders were never going to see us thrive outside. They insisted we will not be better off after Brexit.Anyone who hoped we might be set free to compete on equal terms should read ex-Greek finance minister Yanis Varoufakis’ story of his own country’s punishment beating.It was Varoufakis who compared Brexit with the Eagles’ hit: “It’s like Hotel Calornia — you can check out any time you like, but you can never leave.” And we can blame Phil Hammond for blocking the fire Brexits.But Ms Jourova, a Czech raised under Soviet rule, wants Corbyn-style “regulation” of the free Press.The apple never falls far from the tree.PS. I wonder how M Macron feels after Europe’s Ryder Cup triumph in Paris... without a single French golfer And SIX from the UK!Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bbc press doesnt get tabloids right
story: Theories have ranged from Keeley Hawes’ acting to Richard Madden’s arse, without considering a more obvious possibility.Every other competing drama was either too dull , too grim , or just too rubbish.Which brings me to Press, a series I’d wanted to avoid on the obvious grounds there was never any possibility I was going to like a BBC drama about tabloids.But what the hell. It was a quiet week, so I watched the first four episodes and, to my surprise and delight, I hated Press even more than I expected.The set-up’s the deal-breaker, of course. We’ve got a right-wing red-top called The Post, that’s very obviously meant to be The Sun, and a left-wing broadsheet The Herald, which is equally obviously , house Bible of the BBC.The former is edited by soul-selling clone Duncan Allen, played by the brilliant Ben Chaplin, who does actually resemble a couple of ex-colleagues.By rights then, the female lead should be The Herald’s editor, Amina Chaudury, played by Priyanga Burford.But she can’t act, so the responsibility’s fallen to Charlotte Riley as northern, working-class brick of Deputy News Editor Holly Evans, who fits the social profile of your averagewoman about as comfortably as Roy Chubby Brown fits a mankini.Next weird thing you probably notice about Press is that nearly all the characters are giving speeches, rather than talking normally to each other.Especially the insufferable broadsheet hacks, who never stop reminding each other “we speak the truth to the powerful”, and that “people buy The Herald for the truth”.Why do people buy The Post Sun It’s never really occurred to writer Mike “Doctor Foster” Bartlett, who clearly didn’t read our newspaper before he sat down to type Press, at his desk on the summit of Mount Olympus, and has probably never met a tabloid reader either, without telling them: “Keep the change.”How can I be so sure Because it’s got almost every single professional and technical aspect wrong, from Duncan’s insistence he’s going to do a spread “On page five and six” , to the week one headline The Post produced about the gay, blackmailed footballer who committed suicide: “Parents never knew their son.”Which is the sort of meaningless, esoteric b******s that would get thrown back at a student newspaper sub.That’s another unconvincing thing about Press, incidentally. No one swears. And I wouldn’t mind so muchthere were some decent stories to see us through, but there aren’t.There’s a Katie Hopkins figure floating around, a few cut-and-pasted bits of very old tabloid legendand some deep state conspiracy cobblers, which the BBC’s probably got written into Raa Raa The Noisy Lion these days.Duncan also has the vague hots for Holly, until such time as Ed off the newsdesk tells him she likes having it off in a grey vest.That’s about your lot, though.As always happens when British TV tries to dramatise the Press, the writer’s left-of-centre political agenda and prejudices trump everything .This is why Americans do it so much better, andyou want to see how newspapers really operate you’ll get a much better idea from Billy Wilder’s  film The Front Page than you ever will from Press.I’ll say this for the BBC production team though, they might not have much of an ear for newspaper dialogue, but they’ve got a hell of an eye for interior design and have duplicated one item of our office kitchen crockery perfectly.Mugs.“I don’t bend in the middle any more, to be honest.”Then just slap him around a bit.Improvise, woman.FURTHER proof,it were needed, there’s not a single television format that can’t be improved by the presence of one or two of the Happy Mondays arrived on Friday.A special BBC Music Day edition of Bargain Hunt, featuring Bez and Rowetta versus Pulp’s Jarvis Cocker and Candida Doyle, which will go down in daytime TV folklore.Attempting to keep them in some sort of order, at the Kent showground’s antique fair, was BH regular Charlie Ross, who didn’t get very far with his preliminary question: “How did it all start with the Happy Mondays, Bez ”“You really don’t want to know.”So you really couldn’t blame him for looking a bit nervous when he sent the pair of them away with £ in used notes.Half an hour later, though, Bez and Rowetta were back, with three items, including a biscuit tin and a to-die-for rustic, bygone horse collar mirror that’s yours for just  quid.It made them a respectable £ profit at auction, as well, and flattened Pulp’s efforts in the process.At which point things got a bit dark.Charlie noted “an irregularity”, the Mondays were hauled back on set, like guilty schoolkids, and the host was forced to explain that the winsome and very obliging woman at the back of the auction hall, who kept bidding for his items was in fact: “Bez’s girlfriend.”Not angry, Bez, just disappointed.IF you’ve never seen the brilliant Simpsons episode where Homer gives Pinchy, his pet lobster, a really hot bath, Google it as soon as you can.Then immediately after, watch Channel ’s darkly funny latest episode of Celebrity Island With Bear Grylls, where a pig wandered into camp, on Sunday night.Even more obligingly it then started fattening itself up on the celebs’ leftovers and inviting the obvious by crapping its load everywhere.While some sensed dinner, Towie’s Pete Wicks had a better idea.He named the pig Colin, took it for a walk and then tethered it with a rope to some rocks.Whereupon Colin, with the sort of demonic squeals and grunts you last heard on Deliverance, promptly strangled himself to death.Presented with this tragedy, you or I or Martin Kemp from Spandau Ballet, might’ve drawn the obvious conclusion and, like Homer Simpson, tucked in Not this lot.Instead Colin was buried at sea, with full military title: budget must put money in pockets
story: For all the wise words in his conference speech — on the opportunities of new technology, the horric dangers of Corbyn’s socialism and the importance of job-creating businesses — he needs answers to more immediate questions.The signs are ominous. The Chancellor, while admitting “st Century capitalism must deliver” for ordinary people, apparently intends to take MORE of our money for the NHS in his upcoming Budget.Polls apparently show voters are OK with that. But wait till it comes out of wage packets. Skint workers won’t thank the Tories for bailing out the health ­service. They’ll desert them for grabbing yet more of their take-home pay.Mr Hammond’s speech wasn’t all bad. His case against socialism was well put. Likewise his view that no sane party should try to outbid Corbyn’s ruinous spending pledges. We welcome his proposed digital services tax on Google and Facebookit can be made to work. ut Tory fortunes hinge on Brexit — and pay rises easily outstripping inflation.The Budget MUST put more money in pockets . . . not remove it with a tax raid or a suicidal rise in fuel duty.THE EU’s cry-bullies are OUTRAGED that Jeremy Hunt compared their aggression to the old Soviet Union. Well, diddums.He noted, quite reasonably, that Brussels’ forcible attempts to lock Britain in and deter others from leaving was ­reminiscent of the Soviet empire’s treatment of its member states.It is a figure of speech. The Foreign Secretary’s not literally comparing Juncker to Stalin’s regime of mass murder. And the EU has no defence. Which is why its lackeys, such as curtain-haired clown Guy Verhofstadt, instead wilfully misinterpreted him for dramatic effect.One even whined it could “damage relations” with other member states. Are they for real  The French president brands Brexit campaigners “liars” — implying .million Brits are dupes. Donald Tusk humiliates our PM. title: more young people are feeling lonely
story: The Eleanor Rigby of Beatles legend: “All the lonely people, where do they all come from ”An answer emerged this week — and they come from a surprising place.The loneliest people are healthy, thriving young adults, kicking off their career and probably renting a room in a city.According to new university research for the BBC, levels of loneliness are highest among  to -year-olds, with  per cent saying they often, or very often, feel it. In contrast, the over-s are positively chipper: Only  per cent of this group reported feelings of isolation.Now, I’m  and, depressingly, these statistics don’t surprise me.At first glance, it looks like young people have it easy when it comes to making friends.At  or thereabouts, more than  per cent of them will be packed off to university where they’ll move in with a group of like-minded people of the same age and be encouraged to drink and party like there’s no tomorrow.Which, when you’re only required to stumble out of bed for one pm lecture, there essentially isn’t.Rather than relying on friends of tenuous friends for dubious introductions, young people these days can simply download an app and get the details of thousands of eligible strangers delivered straight to their mobile phones.Add into the mix social media ­— which allows its users to connect with everyone they’ve ever met instantaneously at any given moment — and it’s hard to imagine how any young people could possibly be lonely, let alone  per cent.But there are two sides to every coin.University — though a godsend when it comes to meeting new people — can be a problem when it comes to staying in touch with them. Saddled with bottomless debt, young graduates simply don’t have the cash to socialise.When a round for six at a London pub will set you back  quid, is it any wonder that more and more young people are opting to stay at home Dating apps, too, come with their pitfalls. Yes, it’s nice to have a database of singletons in your pocket, but the ubiquity of Tinder and Bumble mean it’s now considered almost socially awkward to speak to someone you fancy in person.A friend of mine, who has absolutely no problem propositioning women on Tinder, hasn’t yet found the courage to ask for his next-door neighbour’s number, four months after she moved in.As for social media, young people like me are increasingly discovering that “staying connected” is a mixed blessing at best. With no excuse to lose touch, my generation holds on to friends we’ve outgrown, leaving us with no time to make new ones. It may sound callous, but there’s an art to shedding friends, and thanks to our social media addiction, we seem to have lost it.What’s more, earnest  to -year-olds seem to be taking to heart the faddish health advice that adults have been merrily ignoring for years, making it even harder for them to socialise because they fear alcohol, and even food.At the end of a recent party I got chatting to a fun young woman, so I suggested some pub grub at a boozer to round off the evening. How wrong I was.She explained in detail she was vegan and on a gluten-free diet , so the pub menu would not cater for her needs.I decided not to pursue it.So I say it’s time snowflake millennials took a bit of responsibility for their own feelings of isolation.Last month commentators wagged their fingers at the big tech companies after a survey by charity YoungMinds revealed a greater number of young people view social media as having a negative impact on the way they feel about themselves than those who report a positive impact.But it was never suggested depressed young people should simply put away their phones and do something .Mollycoddled millennials believe having a thriving social circle is a human right, rather than an ongoing project.Instead of popping to the pub for a pick-me-up with whoever happens to be around, a lonely young person will all too often turn to the internet for a spot of indulgent self-reflection, or to the gym for Insta-friendly self-improvement.As a result, pubs are closing at a rate of  a day, and sites such as Tumblr are overflowing with posters instructing users to “forget the haters” and “shine like the star that you are”.Of course, social media is made to be addictive. But surely putting down a phone can’t be an insurmountable challenge for an educated generation of young people  Dwelling on yourself is the surest route to a lonely lestyle, so instead of posting doleful, introspective memes on social media or clinging to tired old friendships, lonely young people should find the guts to get outside and look outwards.Making and keeping real friends takes work, and it’s time young people started putting the hours in.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may push lock brexit deal
story: The PM will start phoning leaders across Europe’s capitals this morning in a bid to close gaping gaps.Now that the high risk moment of the Tories’ annual conference in Birmingham is over, senior government figures say she is freer to make more potentially controversial compromises.Despite Mrs May’s demand for Brussels to end the new impasse after the Salzburg summit disaster, The Sun can also reveal that secret talks have already reopened.The PM’s chief negotiator Olly Robbins has been in Brussels this week to try to hammer out a backstop plan to ensure no Irish border.One Cabinet minister involved in the process told The Sun: “We need some very fancy footwork to get the Withdrawal Agreement wrapped up by the October council.“But deadlines always concentrate minds.The PM will be hitting the phone hard and we think it’s just about doable.”The EU announced last night that its  leaders will meet to discuss Brexit over dinner on October , the night before the next summit starts.But Britain has been told that the pieces for a orce deal must be in place by the start of that week for national capitals to then consider them.The UK’s new proposal involves “spreading the pain” over where Ireland’s future customs and regulatory borders lie three ways, between the EU, the UK and Ireland.The EU’s plan for a border down the Irish Sea has been firmly rejected by Mrs May.And her bid to collect the EU’s tarfs and keep Britain within a close customs arrangement has been ruled out by Brussels, along with any infrastructure on the Irish border.No wants to agree the full orce deal at the summit on October -, but hold back from writing it into legal text.A further intensive four week negotiation will then take place before another Brexit summit in November to agree the future framework for a UK-EU trade deal, before both are then signed at the same time.Of all the  EU leaders, French president Emmanuel is still seen as the hardest and most important nut to crack, as German boss Angela Merkel is still too distracted by her unstable coalition government in Berlin.Irish PM Leo Varadkar will touch down in Brussels today for talks with chief negotiator Michel Barnier and EU Council president Donald Tusk.EU diplomats are also increasingly hopeful of achieving a major breakthrough on the thorny border issue within two weeks.One EU diplomat told The Sun: Perhaps its one of the elements where we can move.Im more optimistic than I have been for months that a deal is possible. But they cautioned against overinflated expectations, adding: Dont be too hopeful of having white smoke.October is important but its about trying to get some feel good back into the talks and seeing whether there is indeed land in sight.Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab is then expected to go to the Belgian capital next week.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: conservative party brexit unity rod liddle opinion
story: I don’t think Theresa May is going to be on Strictly any time soon. Whoever convinced her it would be dead cool to walk on stage at the party conference and jig about to an Abba song needs a bit of invasive brain surgery, right now.It was like a remake of Re-Animator, or Night Of The Living Dead.There’s no point in Theresa trying to tell us she’s the le and soul of the party and actually a bloody good laugh.We know she isn’t. She’s about as charismatic as an underdone crumpet on a wet Sunday. But she doesn’t need to be Ginger Rogers. She’s the Prime Minister.And you have to give her credit for doggedly sticking to that role. EvenI’m not convinced she’s been doing it terribly well.But on Brexit — God, how mind-numbingly boring the whole thing is — she has a good point.I’m not a fan of her Chequers deal for us to leave the European Union. I think we’re giving too much away. I’d rather have a no-deal exit.But time is pressing. And I’m aware that while we Leavers won the referendum, the margin was comparatively small. So we ought to be gracious and accept a little bit of a compromise. Try to strike a respectable deal with those gangsters from insignicant countries.And a little further down the line, tweak the arrangements a little to suit us better. In the meantime, just strike the deal.And that means getting behind May and presenting a united front to Europe. Most of the Conservative MPs understand that, even the arch-Brexiteers like the excellent Michael Gove.But Bfo the Blundering Bear does not. I’m talking about Boris Johnson. Now he IS fun and good company. But he’s about as likely to become Prime Minister as I am to cop off with Emily Ratajkowski after a few pints and a quick meal at the Chicken Cottage.He has very little support among his political colleagues. He has a lot more among Conservative activists. But very little among voters north of Watford.And yet Bfo was at it again this week. Taking the p**s out of the Prime Minister. And making a rousing speech to his hardcore supporters. Demanding we tell the EU to stuff it.Well, there was a time when we should have told the EU to stuff it — two years ago when we first started negotiations.That time has passed. A lack of confidence from the Government and a ided party let us down.Now is the time to show a bit of unity and wring a deal out of the deathly bureaucrats. Maybe not the Chequers deal — May didn’t mention the word at all during her speech — but a version of it.Otherwise we’ll have a General Election on our hands. One the Tories will lose. And you’ll wake up to find John McDonnell is in charge of your finances and Diane Abbott is Home Secretary.Come on — surely that should concentrate the mind a little Hero of the week is Jane Lunnon, head of a girls’ school in South London.She has stuck the boot into “image-obsessed” reality TV – especially that coven of gurning and pouting imbeciles in Love Island, such as Megan Barton Hanson.Such programmes are “incredibly damaging” to young people, she reckons, calling them “trivial nonsense”.I think Jane is right. And the same goes for all those hyped-up talent shows where people with no talent – just a lust for fame – get judged on their appalling performances by people with no talent.Kids need to know the dference between fame for fame’s sake – and real achievement.Its horrible that Corine Remande has lost the sight in one eye after she was hit by a golf ball during the Ryder Cup.The poor woman was standing among spectators when Brooks Koepka’s tee shot hit her in the face.She’s now threatening legal action against the organisers. She says they didn’t give spectators enough protection.This is ludicrous. What were they supposed to do And what will happen is that in future crowds will be kept even further back from the action. Just because of one horrible accident.Wait until the same thing happens in cricket...The uni magazine said: “It was argued that the loud noise of traditional clapping and whooping pose an issue to students with anxiety or sensory issues. BSL clapping – or, jazz hands – would be a more inclusive form of expression.”With anxiety or sensory issues  What is wrong with these people They are “triggered” by almost everything. Especially by people who have views which dfer from their own.That REALLY triggers them. They shouldn’t be at university. They should be safe at home with mummy and daddy.That old windbag Mahathir Mohamad has been visiting the UK.Lovely to have him, of course. He’s the boss of Muslim-dominated Malaysia and he hates Jews.He was at it again over here. Said they all had “hook noses”.And that they were the cause of all the trouble in the Middle East.He’s allowed his view, of course, evenit is one based on hatred and the ideology of his own interpretation of his religion.But how would it beI said Muslims are the cause of most of the trouble in the world I’d be up before the Old Bill for a hate crime before you could say Islamic State.This is because Asian countries are getting more and more wealthy.I suppose this is a good thing. Problem is, I can’t stand them, the middle class.And the thought of nearly four billion people eating avocado on toast while doing Pilates then listening to Coldplay in their Volvo XCs makes me feel terribly queasy.The human race is being taken over by the legions of the smug. Get me outta here.Visitors to the Telford Exotic Zoo were disappointed by the penguins. They just stood, stock still.This is because they are plastic model penguins. The zoo had been unable to get the real thing.And here’s a tip for the zoo owners. Don’t buy any real penguins, stick to the models.I think plastic penguins would be far better suited to an enclosure of a dozen square yards of shingle with a tiny drainage ditch to bathe in.Why are we allowing zoos like this to open  If I were a real penguin in Telford Exotic Zoo I’d sue them. Or beat them about the head with a flipper.Have you seen Vladimir Putin’s new calendar There he is, standing naked in water, muscles rippling, looking stern.Another one has him cuddling a baby leopard.I hate to say this but isn’t it all a bit... um... camp And now for saying this I’ll probably end up resembling one of the glow sticks the kids buy at funfairs.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: rooting against cashless britain
story: But in just ten years’ time, kids will find the idea of a porcelain container for metal coins ridiculous — and will be doing their saving on a phone app with cute graphics.Face it, cash is dying out. It is dirty and unhygienic — a report out this week said it is a breeding ground for bugs.There is even a version of Monopoly with debit cards instead of notes. And last month we told you of the  century The Boot pub in Freston, Suffolk, the first boozer in the country to go cashless.This looming death has been around for a while. In August, the Bank of England said it was considering phasing out p and p coins. And ATMs are closing at a rate of  a month.Just  per cent of payments are cash, down from  per cent in . And those payments only account for three per cent in terms of the value of how much is spent.Paying on card has been on the rise ever since Barclaycard launched in , but cards too face being eclipsed by payments on mobile phones. Either way, both mean we need cash less. And that is not a bad thing, right Getting rid of cash would hit criminals and tax evaders hard as they do business in cash to make it harder for authorities to track the movement of money.Businesses would rejoice because they would not have to pay security guards to transport money and would not have to spend ages counting and bagging it.Some also reckon it is easier to keep a tab on finances when spending on cards or apps. You might forget buying that extra round at closing time in the pub, but your phone will always remember. And of course, you get consumer protection when using a credit card, along with reward points or cashback offers.Credit card firms make their money not just from interest payments but from taking a small fee for each transaction — so they offer us incentives to choose their cards. Use an Air Miles card and before long you could have a free flight to Paris or New York.More than a quarter of clothes in the UK are bought online — and you can’t use cash over the internet. As we move even more to buying online and via smartphone apps, cash will be needed less and less. Whether cash dies out in five years or  or  just depends on technology.But many are in no rush to see the back of it — and not just because of nostalgia for their old piggy banks. One consideration is: Can we entirely trust the banks to look after our money  Fraud is soaring as criminals take advantage of security issues around online banking. Banks blame customers but critics say banks need to take responsibility.We have featured victim after victim on The Sun Money columns, and they all say bank staff have turned their backs on them. There are millions of others who need cash simply because they rely on it to pay for things day to day. And it is the less well off or elderly who rely on it the most.Consumer magazine Which  — which has been campaigning against the loss of banks and ATMs — has produced research showing poorer families and older folk are hardest hit.Gareth Shaw of Which  said: “ATM and branch closures are threatening to leave behind the millions who still rely on cash. Our research highlights lower-income families and older generations will be among the worst hit.”In June, services from Visa, one of the three main card providers along with Mastercard and American Express, went down with technical issues — highlighting the risk of being solely reliable on cards and phones. “When the trolley came around on the train and the card payment wasn’t working, the only people who could eat were those with cash,” one banker explained.And what about hospitality workers  The Government has said all tips, evenon cards, must go to staff — but we all know some unscrupulous bosses will not do that. Like many, I prefer to give my tips in cash so I know the waiter or waitress gets it all.Charity collectors often have card machines now but collections for most churches, schools and small local good causes still rely on tins and the rattle of coins.Cash may well be dying out, but I still make sure I always keep some coins in my pocket just in case. And I have older relatives who still feel most comfortable with coins and notes.So until we have a population where everyone feels happy when using a card or phone, I will be rooting against a completely cashless Britain.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: moment 30000 vintage sports car is sent flying into regents canal after being shunted by van
story: The blue  Chesil  Speedster - a replica of the classic Porsche  - was parked outside AutoVero luxury dealership in Islington, north London, when it was shunted.AutoVero boss Kalvin Cauldwell was standing nearby when he heard a massive bang and turned to see his speedster noseing into Regents Canal at around noon yesterday.He told The Sun Online: The car was mid air when I saw it, going skywards before noseing into the canal.There were literally bits of car flying off it in every direction. I knew instantly it was my car.I was with a mechanic dealing with a Ferrari and I heard a smashing noise. It was a massive bang.The van driver was sat there staring into space afterwards. He nearly went in too.It took workers around six hours to fish the submerged speedster from the canal. Mr Cauldwell, of Derbyshire, said it was completely totalled.He added: That car has only just been painted as well. It was only parked outside so I could photograph it.The most expensive car in Mr Cauldwells stock is a rare  Aston Martin V worth £,.Many social media users who witnessed the splash thought the submerged speedster was an original Porsche , which is priced at around £,.The AutoVero director added: It could have been much worse, definitely. It is just an item of stock at the end of the day, not my pride and joy.The driver managed to slide past a Mercedes that was there as well.I park my cars there all the time, you just dont dream that somebody is going to do that.He is now preparing to deal with insurers and expects the car is a total loss.He added: I have never ever had a claim like this before and I doubt I will have one again.AutoVero is the sole distributor of Vintage Speedsters in the UK.It is not yet know why the van driver reversed into the car, but it is believed to have been an accident.The Sun Online has asked the politan Policethey are investigating the incident.

title: schools shut london false widow spiders
story: Two primary schools and two secondary schools have closed after Britains most venomous spider was found on site.The discovery of the spiders were made by Newhams Environmental Team in east London.Pest control teams are now working to bring the outbreak under control before any more eggs hatch.One of the schools affected, Rokeby secondary in Canning Town, will remain shut until October .Star Primary in Beckton, Ellen Wilkinson Primary in Canning Town and Lister Community School in Plaistow have also had to close until further notice.Rokeby head teacher, Charlotte Robinson, said a pest control company estimated it would take three weeks to clear the spiders.In a letter to parents of the school’s  pupils, she wrote: “I have had to take the dficult decision to close Rokeby School to students and staff until Monday, October .“We have engaged a company to deal with and eradicate this pest, they have estimated that this will take up to three weeks.“The safety and wellbeing of students and staff must be our priority so whilst I understand that this may be very inconvenient for you it is in your child’s best interest to remain at home and not at school.”Lister Community School head teacher Anthony Wilson said he hoped his school would re-open by Friday.He added: “Investigations suggest that there may be some of these spiders on our site, and we are therefore following advice from the local authority and will be closing the school as a precaution to allow full investigation.”Lisle Von Buchenroder, headteacher at Star Primary and Sue Ferguson, headteacher of Ellen Wilkinson said they were looking at alternative venues so lessons could continue.False widow spiders are about the size of a p coin and are the most dangerous spider species in the UK.Their bites can be very painful and leave small puncture marks on the skin.A Newham Council spokeswoman said: “The spiders only bitemishandled or provoked. The venom is not particularly potent.“The schools are being treated and fumigated and we are working with the schools to ensure that children can continue to receive an education whilst their school is closed.Pupils are being set work via the schools and will remain in contact with schools.“We are asking all our schools and nurseries to proactively check their premises carefully for these spiders andthey see any signs, then contact environmental health or pest control.”False widow spiders are distinctive for their shiny, black flesh, bulbous bodies, thick legs and skull-like patterns.Millions of  widows, Britains most venomous spider, have been found across the UK and the population is believed to be growing.The species has a brown bulbous abdomen with cream markings that look like a skull. They have long legs and can reach about mm in size.Also known as steatoda nobilis, the spider is frequently confused for the black widow, which has deadly venom.

title: moment 30000 litres of prosecco bursts from tank after an explosion at italian winery
story: Prosecco lovers around the world wished they could have raised a glass – or even a bucket – to help scoop up the bubbly waterfall.The pressurised tank exploded in Conegliano, Veneto, in the province of Treviso, with video footage of the wasted wine posted on Facebook by the Lenoteca Zanardo Giussano winery.But instead of being popping mad, the Prosecco producers simply confessed there was “too much must in the silos”.Must is freshly crushed wine juice that contains the skins, sees and stems of grapes, which is used for fermentation.Seeing the popular Italian sparkling wine cascading onto the floor was too much for some Prosecco fans, with one posting that people should “observe a minute of silence” while others described it as a “tragedy” and a “waste”.More than million people have watched video footage of the , litres of booze overflowing after Zanardo Guissano posted the dramatic event on its Facebook page.Among them was Shane McLeod Brennan, who said: “I would grab as many containers, bottles, bags, cups and the report would be ‘Shane died doing what he loved the most’ attempting to drink a , litre bottle of wine.”Upset Prosecco fan Marco Cerizzi said: “Noooooo. If they had called us we would have dried up the excess!”Giovanni Pianegonda pointed out: “Once it was said: rather than lose a drop, it is better to drink a puddle.”“We cry together for the serious loss!” wrote one grieving wine drinker, while another admitted: “I would have showered under that gorgeous waterfall.”There was also the more dramatic: “Dont want to live in this world anymore.”

title: theresa may dancing abba trolled guy verhofstadt
story: Brussels’ chief spokesman Margaritis Schinas was asked about the Prime Minister’s on-stage antics yesterday, when she walked out to “Dancing Queen”.He responded with the names of several other of the Swedish band’s songs – adding that “breaking up is never easy, I know”.It came after Mrs May was last night trolled by EU Parliament boss Guy Verhofstadt, who evidently missed the funny side of her light-hearted move at the Tory conference in Birmingham.On Twitter last night he sneered: While dancing to ABBA today, PM May overlooked the fact that Bjorn from ABBA called Brexit a disaster.He shared a link to the singer discussing why he wanted Britain to stay in the bloc, which was filmed before the referendum in  where most Brits opted to leave.But Winston Churchills grandson Nicholas Soames was quick to hit back with a tweet saying: #ohbuggeroff!Today Mr Schinas was asked by a reporter an Abba-themed question, whether he would: “Take a chance on May or is Britain facing its Waterloo ”And he replied in kind, saying: My my, how can I resist you. We appreciate a bit of dancing - it always takes two to tango.“We prefer that the tune was Dancing Queen rather than the Winner Takes It All. What can I say  Breaking up is never easy, I know.The PM’s moves did win some plaudits among the EU though, with Swedens ambassador saying last night: I can only say Bravo to Theresa May for starting her conference speech with ABBAs Dancing Queen.Mrs Mays dancing yesterday sent the internet wild with hilarious memes.Social media went into meltdown after she once again showed off her moves at the start of her speech this afternoon.The Tory leader went viral earlier this year after she danced with schoolchildren in South Africa - and didnt hesitate to show off her moves again as she took to the stage in Birmingham.Sharing a meme of Strictly judge Craig Revel Horwood, one joked: I can only assume that the reason Theresa May is dancing so much recently is so that she has a shot at getting on Strictly in  once she gets forced out.Mrs May also used her speech to announce a freeze to fuel duty for another year, a council house revolution by lting the cap on how much authorities can borrow - and revealed the pain of losing her goddaughter to cancer as she unveiled a new strategy to detect diseases earlier.

title: andrea leadsom refuses back theresa may brexit
story: Andrea Leadsom refused to back the PM staying in No after Brexit, and would only say politics is a short term game.Speaking after Mrs May impressed crowds at the Tory party conference in Birmingham yesterday, the leader of the Commons wouldnt say she should stay for the long term.She told ITVs Peston: Thats all for the future.I just think politics is a short term game. A week changes a lot.Although the PMs former leadership rival praised her make-or-break conference day as fantastic she wouldnt offer her full support.I think shes had a fantastic day today. Shes shown some enormous priorities around future cancer prevention through housing supply and absolutely her commitment to getting a good Brexit, she went on.And I think we should all be backing her.Stepping down was a matter for her, she added.Many Tories have privately said they want her to step down after Brexit happens next March.But the PM has not yet said she has any intention to quit her job, and has repeatedly said shes in it for the long term.Even Tories who are unhappy with her leadership admit theres not time to get rid of her and hold a leadership contest now - especially as the talks with the EU reach a crunch point in the coming weeks.Mrs May is back at work today, launching a -day push to lock down a orce deal ahead of the EU summit headline.She will be phoning leaders across Europe this morning to try and secure agreement.The PM’s chief negotiator Olly Robbins has been in Brussels this week to try to hammer out a backstop plan to ensure no Irish border.One Cabinet minister involved in the process told The Sun: “We need some very fancy footwork to get the Withdrawal Agreement wrapped up by the October council.The PM will be hitting the phone hard and we think it’s just about doable.”The EU announced last night that its  leaders will meet to discuss Brexit over dinner on October , the night before the next summit starts.A further intensive four week negotiation will then take place before another Brexit summit in November to agree the future framework for a UK-EU trade deal, before both are then signed at the same time.The Irish PM is in Brussels today for talks with EU bosses, as the Northern Irish border continues to be a sticking point in Brexit talks.Mrs Mays DUP allies wont accept anything that virtually breaks up Northern Ireland with the rest of the UK, but stubborn Brussels chiefs are still refusing to compromise over their hard-line demands.Just minutes before Mrs May gave her speech yesterday one of her critics said hed sent a letter of no confidence in her to the partys chairman.James Duddridge said he no longer wanted her to lead the Tories and failing to remove her as leader could lead to Jeremy Corbyn winning the next election.I write this with heavy heart, however we now need a proper leadership election and to move on, he said.It needs  letters for Mrs May to face a leadership challenge, but she will need at least  of her own MPs to vote to actually boot her out.   Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: homeowner stunned to find 6ft snake lurking in her sewing room so can you spot it
story: The snake hid itself in amongst the clutter of the room, but can YOU spot the scaly visitor Snake Catchers Brisbane, Logan, Ipswich and Gold Coast were called out to the Sherwood property in Brisbane, Australia, yesterday.The Queensland base snake snaring service said on Facebook: “We got called out to a snake that had made itself quite comfortable here in a sewing room.”Snake catcher Jasmine Zeleny identied the scaly stowaway as a coastal carpet python measuring more than six foot in .She said: “They can reach as long as three metres .“Theyre a non-venomous species, and they do very well in an urban environment.”Jasmine added that it was one of the most commonly caught snakes in Brisbane and generally ate rats and possums.She suspects the python crept in the easy way adding: “Sometimes its as simple as leaving the door to the room open.”The snake catching group posted the photo of the snake to their Facebook page, and teased users to seethey could spot the reptile.Bemused users have piled in with their thoughts and comments on the stealthy serpent.One said: “That gives me the heebie jeebies.”Another took aim at the tidiness off the room joking: “This is not a sewing room. title: clear simple pregnancy tests recalled wrong results
story: Some , faulty Clear and Simple digital pregnancy tests are being recalled after a number of the at-home testing kits provided  positive results.The Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agencyhas issued a recall of the affected batches.Dr Duncan McPherson, clinical director of medical devices at the MHRA, said: It is important people check the lot number of any Clear  Simple Digital Pregnancy Tests they have purchased to seethey have a product from an affected lot.If you have any questions about using digital pregnancy tests, please speak to your healthcare professional.Patient safety is our highest priority. We strongly encourage anyone to report any issues with this product, or more generally with any medical device, to our yellow card scheme.”Catalogue number: DM-Lot number: DMEExpiration date: Jan If you pregnancy test is from this batch you shouldit to your pharmacy.Tests on a number of kits from this batch have produced  positive results.A  positive pregnancy test result means youre not pregnant but the test says you are, a heartbreaking scenario for many women.Home tests work by detecting levels of the pregnancy hormone human chorionic gonadotropinin your wee.HAVE YOU BEEN AFFECTED  Email us at andrea.downey@the-sun or call   . You can WhatsApp us on   .Some ask you to hold the stick in a cup of your pee for a few seconds, others ask you to pee with what seems like impossible accuracy, directly on to the stick.There are many things that can cause a  positive result, from using the test wrong to hormone imbalances and medication.In this case, a fault in the design of the Clear and Simple test meant more urine could pass through the testing strip, leading to a  positive result.Home tests work by detecting levels of the pregnancy hormone human chorionic gonadotropinin your wee.Most tests are about  per cent accurate when used correctly, but they are NOT fail-proof.Clear and Simple tests are being recalled for a manufacturing fault, but there are other reasons a test can tell you youre pregnant when youre not.Heres some of the reasons you may experience a  positive result.

title: eus donald tusk piles on more pressure for theresa may to chuck chequers for a canada style brexit deal
story: In a furious attack the EU Council chief doubled down on his hard-line stance in Salzburg and accused the PM of wasting time by throwing around insults.The Pole also raged at Jeremy Hunt over his comparison of the EU to the Soviet Union, branding the foreign secretarys remarks insulting.Mr Tusk risked also enraging Downing Street by endorsing a Canada style trade deal over its beleaguered Chequers plan, to the delight of Brexiteers.He said: From the very beginning, the EU offer has been not just a Canada deal, but a Canada plus plus plus deal.Much further-reaching on trade, on internal security and on foreign policy cooperation.And he added: This is a true measure of respect. And this offer remains in place. The EU is serious about getting the best possible deal.The EUs Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier suggested last month Britain would have to settle for a Canada-style trade deal - which is what many Brexiteers want too.But Mrs May has ruled it out - saying it would break up Northern Ireland from the rest of the UK.She said a No Deal situation would be better than the Canada model as it would be bad for the country.In a searing address Mr Tusk also lashed the foreign secretary over his Soviet Union jibe and the PM over her demand Brussels shows more respect.Mr Hunt was blasted earlier this week of accusing the EU of seeking to punish the UK to keep the club together.And today Mr Tusk fumed: In respecting our partners, we expect the same in . Comparing the EU to the Soviet Union is as unwise as it is insulting.Unacceptable remarks that raise the temperature will achieve nothing except wasting more time. What needs to be done is maximum progress.Now the Tory party conference is over we should get down to business.Senior eurosceptics leapt on the EU chiefs remarks and warned Mrs May she will end up with no deal at allshe perseveres with Chequers.Tory MEP David Campbell Bannerman told The Sun: “This is the first time the EU has been so explicit about welcoming a Super Canada deal.Theyre not offering the ‘simple trade deal’ referred to and rejected in May’s speech - this is bigger, better, wider.And ex-Brexit Minister Steve Baker said: I am deeply encouraged that President Tusk wants a deal and is clear about the framework of that deal.This does once again reinforce that Eurosceptic Conservatives are campaigning for what the EU wants to give us...Leading eurosceptic Jacob Rees-Mogg said: This is a good solution for everyone and the ERGs proposals for the Irish border mean it could work for the UK as a whole.Brexiteer MP Bernard Jenkin added: Hooray! Tusk and the ERG agree on Canada plus plus plus. The problem with Chequers is it asks too much of the EU, needs too many concessions or ‘cherries’.But the EU must concede that the Irish border issue is resolvable via checks away from the border, not via backstop which threatens to ide the UK.He went on: This can be the basis of an excellent deal that gets through Westminster and the European Parliament and Council.It’s time to recognise Chequers is not going to work and will merely result in no deal.And ex Ukip leader Nigel Farage implored: Please Mrs May, bite his hand off.
